intro: Rhytiglossa microphylla, commonly known as the small-leaved mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and typically grows on the branches of host trees such as oaks and pines. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually arranged in opposite pairs along its stems. Its flowers are small and clustered, often appearing in greenish-white or yellowish hues. Rhytiglossa microphylla relies on its host for water and nutrients, while it provides some degree of protection to the host tree through its parasitic relationship.
